courses.Subject: RMER
courses.Title: Selling Techniques & Strategies
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="560" dept="RMER" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Taking a seminar approach, this course applies inquiry and interpretation of sales strategies as essential planning for a retail business. Students will examine various types of selling strategies and how they influence the retail environment.

courses.Subject: RMER
courses.Title: Research & Data Collection
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="697" dept="RMER" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This rigorous course is designed to develop understanding and experience in empirical research in order to build and design a final project or thesis. Emphasis will be placed on data collection, organization, interpretation and presentation. Students will follow-up with their instructor through web-based platforms and will be required to turn-in reports and output for their project or thesis.

courses.Subject: RMER
courses.Title: Retail Supply Chain Analysis
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="570" dept="RMER" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course presents the concepts, practical tools, and support systems that are important to effective interaction with retail supply chains considering the lifestyle products of apparel, footwear, home goods and beauty. Strategic design and tactical and operational issues will be examined including retail and merchandising support technology such as CAD, PDM, PLM, RFID and EDI. Emerging concepts related to globally optimal decision-making will be emphasized.

courses.Subject: RMER
courses.Title: Project/Research Thesis
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="698" dept="RMER" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This final course will build the student¿s concentrated coursework producing a finalized project or thesis (such as a publishable academic journal article) synthesizing an area of Retail & Merchandising based upon their specific research and data collection. Students will be responsible for working with their course professor on the final outcome that documents the proposal, base research and conclusions.

courses.Subject: TVPR
courses.Title: Producing for Television
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="240" dept="TVPR" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course introduces students to the art and craft of producing for television and examines every aspect of the producer¿s role in the developing, selling, pre-production, production, post-production, delivery, and marketing of a show.  Students will also learn the functions of all other jobs involved in a producation.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Television Production
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="630" dept="TVMN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Television Production.  Television production techniques in common use at local television stations are taught including multi-camera (studio) production, single camera (film style) production, and basic editing techniques.  Throughout the term, the course also examines production issues from a manager's point-of-view.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Management of News and Sports Programming
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="680" dept="TVMN" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Management of News and Sports Programming.  Through lectures, case studies, and individual and project work, this course explores management issues in news and sports programming.  Students learn about news and sports journalism, sales/marketing/sponsorship of news and sports programming, legal and ethical issues, personnel issues, market research, technology, and how to critique new sports programming.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Television Practicum
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="700" dept="TVMN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course offers hands-on management experience at Drexel's television station or (with Program Director's approval) at other television stations, cable companies, or related media.  The assumption is that the student will work a minimum of ten hours per week for ten weeks to receive three credits for the term.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Thesis in TV Management
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="790" dept="TVMN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: The thesis will demonstrate the competence to identify a problem or create a project germane to the evolving field on television management, and to produce a work product that is executed in a systematic manner using research and management tools.  The thesis proposal must be approved by the Program Director.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Thesis Completion
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="791" dept="TVMN" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is designed to engage the degree candidate in the process of research, writing and completing the thesis. Enrollment in the course enables the master¿s degree candidate in television management to maintain and enhance contact with the thesis advisor during critical stages in the research process; it also enables the student to gain access to the research resources of the university library. This is a half credit (0.5 credit) course that may be repeated for credit as many times as needed within the limits placed on time for completion of the program by the university.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Media Ethics of Television Management
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="640" dept="TVMN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Media Ethics for TVMN explores issues central to the decision-making process in which media mangers engage.  Case studies in television and evolving media, investigation of contemporary events that reflect ethical dilemmas, and research into the intersection of financial, regulatory, and career considerations with ethical choice are closely examined.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Global TV - London
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="698" dept="TVMN" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Special Topics in Television Management.  This course offers rotating topics in Television Management that could include a closer look at an aspect of management (e.g., contract law and negotiation as it applies to television), an examination of an issue (e.g., violence and TV), or an in-depth analysis of a particular case study (e.g., coverage of a disaster from a manager's point-of-view).  The course (but not the same topic) may be repeated for credit.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Television Programming
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="710" dept="TVMN" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Through lectures, case studies and individual and team projects, this course explores the role of programming in television.  Students learn about development, financial and legal issues, programming distribution, the role of ratings and advertising support in program scheduling, and career opportunities in the field.

courses.Subject: TVMN
courses.Title: Thesis Completion
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="791" dept="TVMN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is designed to engage the degree candidate in the process of research, writing and completing the thesis. Enrollment in the course enables the master¿s degree candidate in television management to maintain and enhance contact with the thesis advisor during critical stages in the research process; it also enables the student to gain access to the research resources of the university library. This is a half credit (0.5 credit) course that may be repeated for credit as many times as needed within the limits placed on time for completion of the program by the university.

courses.Subject: URBS
courses.Title: Public Space and Placemaking
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T580" dept="URBS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is an introduction to the spaces between buildings in an urban environment, their ¿publicness¿, and the programming that takes place within them. These are the places of play and protest, but also streets and sidewalks, as well as ¿semi-public¿ spaces like libraries or airports. The focus of this class will be on the history of these spaces and how they came to be ¿public¿, a greater understanding of the typology of public and private places that we interact with in our public lives, and methodologies with which to assess them. Critical assessment of public space will be key to the class, including how they are used, who is and is not included in the everyday use and creation of these spaces, and how best to design and maintain public space through placemaking principles. Students will come away from this class with a toolkit of methods to use in studying public space through a direct observation ¿spatial ethnography¿ assignment to analyze a public space of their choice in Philadelphia.

courses.Subject: WEST
courses.Title: Public Space and Placemaking
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="WEST" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.

courses.Subject: AFAS
courses.Title: Introduction to Africana Studies
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="AFAS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Provides an overview of the experience, culture, and political practices of African descendants in the Americas and the Caribbean. The course uses a multidisciplinary approach to introduce students to the history, art, music, and literature of the African Diaspora.

courses.Subject: ARBC
courses.Title: Arabic I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="ARBC" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introductory Arabic includes listening, speaking, reading and writing. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: CHEC
courses.Title: Physical Chemistry and Applications III
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="353" dept="CHEC" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Kinetics and spectroscopy; Covers reaction kinetics, steady state approximation, chain reactions and unimolecular reactions, optical spectroscopy; Beer's Law, atomic spectra/simple atomic models, rotational and vibrational spectra, Raman spectra, term symbols and selection rules, lasers, molecular statistics, partition functions.

courses.Subject: CHIN
courses.Title: Chinese I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="CHIN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introductory Mandarin Chinese. Includes listening, speaking, and reading, with individual audiolingual practice. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: CHIN
courses.Title: Chinese II
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="102" dept="CHIN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Continues CHIN 101. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
courses.Section_Comments: Open to students in on-campus programs only
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="CJS" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course provides a survey of the criminal justice system with the primary goal of conveying an understanding of America's formal response to crime. We confront the long-standing struggle to balance due process with crime control through the lenses of the police, courts and corrections -- the core elements of the Criminal Justice system. We also examine major crime control paradigms (historic and current), and the tenuous relationship between race and justice. The course offers a variety of educational approaches in an effort to match (as much as is reasonable) students' individual learning styles and needs.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Introduction to Security Studies
courses.Section_Comments: Open to students in on-campus programs only
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="267" dept="CJS" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course examines the private security industry. Substantive topics of interest include the historical development of the industry; its linkage to public forms of security (law enforcement and the regulatory state); its legal underpinnings; management issues; and the nature of internal and external threats faced by facilities and organizations. The philosophical and analytic paradigm for security -- risk analysis and prevention -- offers a framework for the study of problem solving models used in the field. This framework, along with the analytic models utilized by security professionals will be explored in depth.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Terrorism
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="289" dept="CJS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course examines the varying types and purposes of terrorism and its application. It will discuss the problems with definitions, worldviews and ideologies, and how these affect both the perceptions and responses to terrorist events.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Mental Health & the CJ System
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="CJS" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course will explore current issues and interests in Criminology and Justice Studies. The topic will vary each term.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Criminal Profiling
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="CJS" sect="902" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course will explore current issues and interests in Criminology and Justice Studies. The topic will vary each term.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Crime and the City
courses.Section_Comments: Open to students in on-campus programs only
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="220" dept="CJS" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course reviews the nature of crime and disorder in cities from the urban industrial revolution through the so-called "Crime Drop" of the early 2000s. The course opens with an overview of urbanization, contrasting the ¿best¿ with the ¿worst¿ aspects of the industrial revolution on human life. It then examines urban drug markets, violence, and policing before moving into a discussion of the crime "peak" of 1992. The course then follows the ensuing crime drop, examining demographic, economic, and cultural factors that may explain the national crime decline. The course then focuses on violence as a public health issue and on how crime, incarceration, health, housing, and education are all tied to urban crime policy.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Introduction to Computer Crime
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="276" dept="CJS" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course provides an overview of computer crime. Emphasis will be placed on the legislative responses and policy issues related to computer intrusions and cyberfraud. Issues encountered when informing laws in cyberspace and the public/private sector initiatives for dealing with computer crime will also be explored.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Life Course Criminology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="CJS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course will explore current issues and interests in Criminology and Justice Studies. The topic will vary each term.

courses.Subject: CJS
courses.Title: Victimology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="CJS" sect="901" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course will explore current issues and interests in Criminology and Justice Studies. The topic will vary each term.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: General Ecology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="230" dept="ENVS" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course examines how organisms interact with the biological and physical world and bridges the natural sciences with the social sciences.  Using evolutionary theory as its basis, this course will cover topics spanning multiple levels of organization within the science of ecology.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Environmental Science and Society
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="260" dept="ENVS" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is a multidisciplinary introduction to the range of disciplines that make up the environmental sciences.  The aim of this course is to provide an understanding of basic physical, ecological and social sciences that focus on the study on the natural environment and its interaction with human society.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Marine Field Methods
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="388" dept="ENVS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Course focus is on the ecology of local marine environments. Students learn marine field survey methods, identification of marine organisms, habitat analyses, and use of equipment for measuring abiotic variables. Students sample fish, plankton and invertebrate species aboard the Drexel 25 foot Research Vessel Peter Kilham.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Marine Field Methods
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="588" dept="ENVS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Course focus is on the ecology of local marine environments. Students learn marine field survey methods, identification of marine organisms, habitat analyses, and use of equipment for measuring abiotic variables. Students sample fish, plankton and invertebrate species aboard the 25 foot Drexel research vessel, Peter Kilham.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Environmental Science and Society
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="260" dept="ENVS" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is a multidisciplinary introduction to the range of disciplines that make up the environmental sciences.  The aim of this course is to provide an understanding of basic physical, ecological and social sciences that focus on the study on the natural environment and its interaction with human society.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Field Botany of the New Jersey Pine Barrens
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="382" dept="ENVS" sect="102" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course focuses on plant identification skills that are necessary to conduct scientific botanical surveys.  The vascular flora of the New Jersey Pine Barrens, including rare plant species, is emphasized with special reference to habitat and community analysis.  Non-vascular species are examined but not emphasized.

courses.Subject: ENVS
courses.Title: Field Botany of the New Jersey Pine Barrens
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="582" dept="ENVS" sect="102" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course focuses on plant identification skills that are necessary to conduct scientific botanical surveys.  The vascular flora of the New Jersey Pine Barrens, including rare plant species, is emphasized with special reference to habitat and community analyses.  Non-vascular species are examined but not emphasized.

courses.Subject: GER
courses.Title: German I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Description: Introductory German. Includes listening, reading, writing, and speaking. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: HBRW
courses.Title: Introduction to Hebrew I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="HBRW" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: The goal of this course is to provide a thorough foundation in the Hebrew language.  Small class size provides intensive practice in speaking, writing and listening comprehension.

courses.Subject: ITAL
courses.Title: Italian I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="ITAL" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introductory Italian. Includes listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: JUDA
courses.Title: Politics of Immigration
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T380" dept="JUDA" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the issues associated with immigration from both a US and international as well as a historical and contemporary perspective. Emphasis will be focused on the theory, public policy and philosophical issues that are associated with this area of inquiry.

courses.Subject: LING
courses.Title: Language and Society
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="102" dept="LING" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Develops understanding of how language is involved with relations of class, ethnicity, gender and aesthetics in society.  The course covers the social investigation of language use, politeness in languages, different varieties of English dialects, slang, and rap, bilingualism and languages in immigrant communities, and language planning.

courses.Subject: LING
courses.Title: Foundations of Linguistics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="560" dept="LING" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Foundations of Linguistics provides a foundation in the analysis of language, including topics of phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics.  Using a problem-based approach, students examine areas of language use such as first and second language acquisition, the analysis of world languages other than English, and variation in language use (sociolinguistics).

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Symbolic Logic I
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="111" dept="PHIL" sect="130" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: An introduction to the fundamental concepts of symbolic logic: argument, validity, soundness, provability, completeness, consistency, decidability, entailment, logical equivalence, logical truth, logical contradiction.  Covers truth-functional connectives, rules of formation and translation, and rules of inference.  Proof techniques studied include natural deduction, truth-tables, and/or truth-trees.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Social and Political Philosophy
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="241" dept="PHIL" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Studies theories about human social and political life that bear on philosophical issues such as the nature and scope of justice, the legitimacy of states, and the relationship between democracy, civil rights, and civil disobedience.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Ethics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="251" dept="PHIL" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Studies theories about human conduct which bear upon the rightness and wrongness of actions, and the goodness and badness of ends, including the nature, scope, purposes, and varieties of moral and ethical theories.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Business Ethics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="301" dept="PHIL" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Study of such moral issues as truth-telling, puffery, and lying in business communications; employer-employee relations; obligations to customers; obligations to foreign populations; and government contracts.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Ethics and the Media
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="305" dept="PHIL" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Ethical analysis of current laws and legislation aimed at regulating speech in the context of mass communications (radio, television and film).

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Ethics and Information Technology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="311" dept="PHIL" sect="131" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Ethical analyses of current laws and pending legislation aimed at regulating computer use as well as Internet practices and content.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Engineering Ethics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="315" dept="PHIL" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Provides critical reflection on the nature of engineering and technology and on the ethical obligations and responsibilities unique to the engineering profession. Topics include the social responsibilities of engineering, the nature of professionalism, professional autonomy, whistleblowing, conflicts of interest, organizational (dis)obedience, the ethics of risk assessment, and the place and purpose of engineering codes of ethics.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Engineering Ethics

courses.Description: Provides critical reflection on the nature of engineering and technology and on the ethical obligations and responsibilities unique to the engineering profession. Topics include the social responsibilities of engineering, the nature of professionalism, professional autonomy, whistleblowing, conflicts of interest, organizational (dis)obedience, the ethics of risk assessment, and the place and purpose of engineering codes of ethics.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Biomedical Ethics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="321" dept="PHIL" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Studies moral issues related to health and disease, patients' rights and professional responsibilities, informed consent, abortion, euthanasia, and biomedical research.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Philosophy of Technology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="351" dept="PHIL" sect="130" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Studies technology from a philosophical standpoint stressing its role in shaping human existence and values, considering issues such as the control and distribution of information, housing and city planning, automation, and the uses of technology in medicine.

courses.Description: Provides critical reflection on the nature of engineering and technology and on the ethical obligations and responsibilities unique to the engineering profession. Topics include the social responsibilities of engineering, the nature of professionalism, professional autonomy, whistleblowing, conflicts of interest, organizational (dis)obedience, the ethics of risk assessment, and the place and purpose of engineering codes of ethics.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Engineering Ethics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="315" dept="PHIL" sect="941" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>

Topics include the social responsibilities of engineering, the nature of professionalism, professional autonomy, whistleblowing, conflicts of interest, organizational (dis)obedience, the ethics of risk assessment, and the place and purpose of engineering codes of ethics.

courses.Subject: PHIL
courses.Title: Global Ethical Issues
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="335" dept="PHIL" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Offers an introduction to the ethical tensions of our age, globally construed. May address such issues as terrorism, genocide, religious exclusivism, nuclear proliferation, the regulation of the Internet, as well as culturally competing notions of right and wrong, and good and bad.

courses.Subject: PSCI
courses.Title: Introduction to Political Science
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="100" dept="PSCI" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Studies the political process, which determines who gets what, when, and how in society.

courses.Subject: PSCI
courses.Title: International Politics
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="150" dept="PSCI" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Analyzes nation-states in their external relations, including the interaction of the great powers with each other and with emerging areas.

courses.Subject: PSCI
courses.Title: Politics of Immigration
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="375" dept="PSCI" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the issues associated with immigration from both a US and international as well as a historical and contemporary perspective. Emphasis will be focused on the theory, public policy and philosophical issues that are associated with this area of inquiry.

courses.Title: Introduction to Political Science

courses.Subject: PSCI
courses.Title: International Organizations: The United Nations
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="351" dept="PSCI" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: The goal of this course is to present an overview of the nature and function of international organization in world politics. The role of the United Nations and its agencies are highlighted. Students gain an understanding of how international life is structured through these institutions.

courses.Subject: PLCY
courses.Title: Case Study Research II
courses.Section_Comments: Open to students in on-campus programs only
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="516" dept="PLCY" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: A tutorial course for public policy students to collect and report on original documents (legislation, hearing transcripts, reports, ect) relevant to their chosen case study topics.

courses.Title: Spanish I
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="SPAN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introductory Spanish. Includes listening, speaking, reading, and writing. Offered all terms.

courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="103" dept="SPAN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>

courses.Subject: SPAN
courses.Title: Sanctuary Cities
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="440" dept="SPAN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This courses provides an advanced analysis of power relations and issues of (in)equality rooted in contemporary political and socio-economic systems. The content of this course may change every term it is offered and is repeatable for credit. Taught in Spanish.

courses.Title: Spanish II
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="102" dept="SPAN" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>

courses.Subject: SPAN
courses.Title: Spanish IV
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="201" dept="SPAN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Intermediate Spanish. Includes grammar review, listening, speaking, and reading. Recommended for students who wish to attain oral competence. Offered all terms.

courses.Subject: SPAN
courses.Title: Advanced Writing and Speaking
courses.Section_Comments: Placement test required with prior experience
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="310" dept="SPAN" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course provides advanced practice in written and oral communication including journalistic, professional, and creative writing. Examines contemporary cultural contexts through media and news. This course has a community-based component that will require students to work with members of our community including, but not restricted to Spanish-speaking communities in the area. Taught in Spanish.

courses.Subject: WGST
courses.Title: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="WGST" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Women's and Gender Studies is a field that takes as its themes the study of women and gender, utilizing multi-disciplinary approaches from fields such as history, psychology, philosophy, and sociology. WGST 101 approaches the topics experientially and allows students to explore their own gender and sexuality as living identities.

courses.Subject: WGST
courses.Title: Power, Gender, and Hollywood
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="T280" dept="WGST" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: In 2017, 88 percent of the top 250 films had no female directors, 83 percent had no female writers, and 96 percent had no female cinematographers. When we also consider the overwhelming allegations of sexual harassment, one might wonder if there is any hope for gender equality in Hollywood. In this course, we will attempt to answer that question by tracing a gendered history of film. We will meet landmark figures, examine the relationship between representation and reality, and acquire analytical tools to help us become cannier consumers as well as advocates for change.

courses.Subject: WGST
courses.Title: Introduction to Feminisms
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="201" dept="WGST" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Feminisms are movements to understand and critique gender relations and gender oppression, and also attempts to construct positive visions of human freedom and ethical action in an unjust world. This course is an introduction to the history of feminisms. The major movements that make up feminism in the modern era, in both the U.S. and abroad, will be examined.

courses.Subject: WGST
courses.Title: Masculinities
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="320" dept="WGST" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: An exploration of how masculinity is lived its multiple forms, traditional and alternative, in contemporary Western society. This course aims to arrive at a theory of masculinity ¿ what does it mean to be "masculine"?.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Introduction to Cultural Diversity
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="ANTH" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Introduction to Cultural Diversity
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="ANTH" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Human Past:  Anthropology and Prehistoric Archeology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="110" dept="ANTH" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines human origins from the australopithecines to the present, including both the physiological and archaeological records. Discusses new finds and new interpretations of evolution.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Worldview: Science, Religion and Magic
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="210" dept="ANTH" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines anthropological and archaeological evidence of the worldviews of non-literate people, as shown in the practice of ceremony, magic, sorcery, and witchcraft, and the role of shamans and priests.  This is a writing intensive course.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Media Anthropology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="330" dept="ANTH" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course will introduce students to the anthropological study of media including traditional forms of mass media as well as new media such as the Internet.  Students will be exposed to the theories and methodologies of media study from an anthropological perspective.  Students will also engage in their own ethnographic studies of media to gain first hand experience with the methods of anthropology.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Introduction to Cultural Diversity
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="ANTH" sect="003" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Human Past:  Anthropology and Prehistoric Archeology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="110" dept="ANTH" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Examines human origins from the australopithecines to the present, including both the physiological and archaeological records. Discusses new finds and new interpretations of evolution.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="111" dept="ANTH" sect="900" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Anthropology is the holistic study of the human condition. Biological anthropology is a subfield of the larger discipline that studies humankind as a zoological species. As biological anthropology is firmly rooted in evolutionary theory, the evolutionary biology of humans is the central focus of the course. Basic concepts of genetics, geology, paleontology, comparative anatomy, primate biology and material culture provide the foundation for understanding humanity¿s place in nature.

courses.Subject: ANTH
courses.Title: Anthropology of Gender
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="215" dept="ANTH" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course takes an ethnographic approach to the study of gender socializations and gender roles.  We will address issues of sex roles, the cultural construction of gender categories, the forms of gender inequality, and the ways cultures engage in gender based power relationships.  While these issues will be dealt with in specific and local ethnographic contexts, students will be encouraged to make comparisons across the contexts and to compare these works with their own experience.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Applied Biological Diversity, Ecology & Evolution
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="101" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: An interactive course for the non-major that discusses the variety of living things and how we ended up with them and what makes them unique. This course also explores how living things affect each other and the world as well as the impacts that humans have on the living world. This course is identical to BIO 109

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biological Diversity, Ecology and Evolution Laboratory
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="110" dept="BIO" sect="061" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: A companion course to BIO 109 that provides a hands on exploration of the diversity of life including microbes, plants and animals as well as the processes that give rise to this diversity. The labs also provide practical exploration of the impacts of human beings on the planet.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Essential Biology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="141" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introduces essential biological concepts to engineering students. Content covers five core topics: cells, genetics, evolution, ecology and physiology with application to societal concerns about biotechnology, health, conservation biodiversity and bioethics. Evolution will be woven throughout the course as a unifying theme in understanding all aspects of biology.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Essential Biology
courses.Description: Introduces essential biological concepts to engineering students.  Content covers five core topics: cells, genetics, evolution, ecology and physiology with application to societal concerns about biotechnology, health, conservation biodiversity and bioethics.  Evolution will be woven throughout the course as a unifying theme in understanding all aspects of biology.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Human Physiology II
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="203" dept="BIO" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Intensive survey of the control mechanisms of cellular and human physiology including introductions to control theory, neurophysiology, endocrine control, and control mechanisms in locomotion, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, acid/base, gastrointestinal, and reproductive physiology.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Human Physiology II
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="203" dept="BIO" sect="A" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Intensive survey of the control mechanisms of cellular and human physiology including introductions to control theory, neurophysiology, endocrine control, and control mechanisms in locomotion, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, acid/base, gastrointestinal, and reproductive physiology.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Applications in Biology II
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="208" dept="BIO" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: In this course, students will further develop and practice skills introduced in the Applications in Biology I course by reading and interpreting research from primary articles. This will include historical experiments and controversial research. This will help students develop critical thinking, scientific reasoning and problem solving skills.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Cell, Molecular & Developmental Biology II
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="211" dept="BIO" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: In this course, students will learn about molecular, cellular and developmental biology at a higher level than in introductory coursework. This second course in the sequence will focus on cell biological processes such as: vesicular trafficking, signaling, cytoskeletal dynamics, cell cycle, cell death, tissue organization, stem cells and development. At the end of this course, students should have a strong foundation in cell and developmental biology.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biotechnology
courses.Section_Comments: Open to students in on-campus programs only
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="212" dept="BIO" sect="940" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Covers the use of recombinant DNA techniques in biotechnology.  Explores the many uses of biotechnology in the biological, agricultural and medical field.  Also covers the social, ethical and environmental issues involved in this discipline.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Principles of Molecular Biology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="218" dept="BIO" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: The course is designed to familiarize students with the details and concepts revolving around molecular biology's "central dogma." Specifically the chemical nature of DNA and RNA, the molecular structure of DNA and chromosomes, the definition of a gene, how DNA is replicated, and how genes are expresses and regulated.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Techniques in Molecular Biology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="219" dept="BIO" sect="061" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Designed to familiarize student with laboratory techniques utilized in molecular biology, specifically DNA isolation, characterization, and manipulation. Students work in teams to collect and analyze data and explain results in laboratory reports. Weekly recitations preview and review theory and techniques used in the lab. Some or all pre-requisites may be taken as either a pre-requisite or co-requisite. Please see the department for more information. This is a writing intensive course.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Essential Microbiology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="220" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Covers morphological, physiological, and biochemical characteristics of bacteria, fungi, algae, and protozoa, and viruses. Introduces the principles of microbial genetics, disease, and control of microorganisms. This course is identical to BIO 221.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Microbiology Laboratory
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="222" dept="BIO" sect="062" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: An introduction to microbiological techniques, and culture of prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms. Includes sterile techniques, and use of specialized microscopic techniques. Classical and molecular techniques of microbial identification are also covered.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Form, Function & Evolution of Vertebrates
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="224" dept="BIO" sect="003" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is an introduction to principles of organismal biology from the perspective of form, function and evolution of fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals and birds.   Many biological principles are well known in this group of animals.   Data from areas as diverse as paleontology, ecology and molecular biology will be presented.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Form, Function & Evolution of Vertebrates
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="224" dept="BIO" sect="A" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course is an introduction to principles of organismal biology from the perspective of form, function and evolution of fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals and birds.   Many biological principles are well known in this group of animals.   Data from areas as diverse as paleontology, ecology and molecular biology will be presented.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Vertebrate Biology and Evolution Laboratory
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="225" dept="BIO" sect="063" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: A hands-on laboratory course that complements BIO 224: Form, Function & Evolution of Vertebrates. Students use the comparative approach to learn about the anatomy, physiology and evolution of vertebrates. Laboratory work will be on campus and in the field trips to observe vertebrates in nature.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Microbiology for Health Professionals
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="226" dept="BIO" sect="062" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: An introduction to microbiology for students in the health professions.  Covers the diversity of microorganisms, their growth and how to control them.  An introduction to the principles of disease and pathogenicity, host interaction and immunological response.  Laboratories focus on the basic techniques to culture and student microorganisms.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Dictyostelium Research
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="229" dept="BIO" sect="061" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: We will be developing and progressing molecular and cellular projects to study cellular function in Dictyostelium discoideum as a model to investigate human cellular dysfunction. This exploratory and experimental course is designed to provide opportunities for students to experience authentic laboratory investigation in the context of a course which runs like a research group. Projects progress from term to term so students are welcome to continue in subsequent terms to further progress their projects or switch to other ongoing projects.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Science of Science Fiction
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name=""> <courses>  <course num="T280" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Topics decided upon by faculty will vary within the area of study.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biology of Cancer
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="318" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: In this course, students will apply their studies of cell and molecular biology to understand cancer pathology. Starting with a fundamental knowledge of normal cellular processes, students will learn how normal processes go awry in tumor development and metastasis, and the current approaches being used to develop new cancer therapeutics.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biochemistry of Major Diseases
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="416" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course focuses on the biochemical bases of several selected human disorders including neoplasm, cardiovascular disorders, diabetes and obesity. Biochemical changes ant their regulation by signaling pathways under the disease conditions will be examined. The relevance of diagnosis and treatment will be discussed.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biochemistry of Major Diseases
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="616" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course focuses on the biochemical bases of several selected human disorders including neoplasm, cardiovascular disorders, diabetes and obesity. Biochemical changes and their regulation by signaling pathways under the disease conditions will be examined. The relevance of diagnosis and treatment will be discussed.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Biological Diversity, Ecology & Evolution
courses.Description: An interactive course for the non-major that discusses the variety of living things and how we ended up with them and what makes them unique. This course also explores how living things affect each other and the world as well as the impacts that humans have on the living world. This course is identical to BIO 101

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Basics of Cancer
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="118" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: This course provides an opportunity for students with little or no biology background to learn about cancer. Students can expect to learn what cancer is from a biological perspective, and how it is caused and treated. Students will also gain a basic understanding of how tumors form, and metastasize.

courses.Subject: BIO
courses.Title: Essential Biology
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="141" dept="BIO" sect="002" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>
courses.Description: Introduces essential biological concepts to engineering students. Content covers five core topics: cells, genetics, evolution, ecology and physiology with application to societal concerns about biotechnology, health, conservation biodiversity and bioethics. Evolution will be woven throughout the course as a unifying theme in understanding all aspects of biology.

courses.Title: Human Physiology II

courses.Title: Cell, Molecular & Developmental Biology II
courses.Textbook: http://drexel.bncollege.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/TBListView?cm_mmc=RI-_-457-_-1-_-A&catalogId=10001&storeId=31061&langId=-1& termMapping=N&courseXml=<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>   <textbookorder> <school id="457"/>  <campus name="UC"> <courses>  <course num="211" dept="BIO" sect="001" term="A19" />  </courses>  </campus> </textbookorder>

At the end of this course, students should have a strong foundation in cell and developmental biology.
